title: Category Theory Fundamentals
description: Test your understanding of basic category theory concepts
subject: Category Theory

questions.question: What is a category in category theory?
questions.prereq: Basic understanding of mathematical structures and functions

options.text: A collection of objects with morphisms between them, satisfying composition and identity laws
A set with a binary operation
A type of mathematical function
A collection of sets with inclusion relations

questions.question: What must be satisfied for composition of morphisms f: A → B and g: B → C?
questions.prereq: Understanding of categories, objects, and morphisms

options.text: The codomain of f must equal the domain of g
f and g must be bijective
f and g must commute
f and g must have the same type

questions.question: What is a functor?
questions.prereq: Knowledge of categories and structure-preserving mappings

options.text: A mapping between categories that preserves structure
A special type of morphism within a category
An object that can be mapped to itself
A category with exactly one object
options.concept: Confusing functors with monoids as one-object categories

questions.question: In the category Set, what are the objects and morphisms?
questions.prereq: Basic set theory and understanding of categories

options.text: Objects are sets, morphisms are functions between sets
Objects are functions, morphisms are sets
options.concept: Confusing objects and morphisms in Set

options.text: Objects are elements, morphisms are sets containing them
options.concept: Confusing set elements with set objects

options.text: Objects are categories, morphisms are functors

questions.question: What is a natural transformation?
questions.prereq: Advanced knowledge of functors and commutative diagrams

options.text: A way of transforming one functor into another while respecting the categorical structure
A functor that maps each object to itself
options.concept: Confusing natural transformations with identity functors

options.text: A morphism that exists in every category
options.concept: Confusing natural transformations with universal properties

options.text: A transformation that preserves composition in the obvious way
options.concept: Missing the key naturality square condition

category-vs-algebraic.description: Difficulty distinguishing categories from algebraic structures like groups or rings
category-vs-algebraic.recommendation: Study how categories generalize algebraic structures by focusing on morphisms rather than operations
resources: Category Theory for Programmers - Bartosz Milewski
Categories for the Working Mathematician - Saunders Mac Lane
Visual introduction to category theory diagrams

category-vs-function.description: Misunderstanding categories as being functions rather than structures containing morphisms
category-vs-function.recommendation: Focus on understanding categories as mathematical structures with objects and arrows, not functions themselves

category-vs-set-theory.description: Conflating categorical structures with set-theoretic constructions
category-vs-set-theory.recommendation: Learn how category theory abstracts away from set membership to focus on structural relationships
resources: Category theory as an alternative foundation

composition-requirements.description: Misunderstanding what is required for morphisms to be composable
composition-requirements.recommendation: Practice composing morphisms and understand the domain/codomain matching requirement

composition-vs-commutativity.description: Confusing morphism composition with commutativity of operations
composition-vs-commutativity.recommendation: Study examples where composition is associative but not necessarily commutative
resources: Group theory vs category theory comparison

functor-vs-morphism.description: Difficulty distinguishing between functors (mappings between categories) and morphisms (arrows within categories)
functor-vs-morphism.recommendation: Study the levels: objects and morphisms within categories, functors between categories

functor-vs-object.description: Misunderstanding functors as objects rather than mappings between categories
functor-vs-object.recommendation: Focus on functors as arrows at the category level, mapping between entire categories

functor-vs-monoid.description: Confusing functors with monoids viewed as one-object categories
functor-vs-monoid.recommendation: Study how monoids can be seen as categories, but functors are mappings between any categories
resources: Examples of functors between different category types

object-morphism-confusion.description: Mixing up what serves as objects versus morphisms in specific categories
object-morphism-confusion.recommendation: Practice identifying objects and morphisms in various concrete categories
resources: Category examples: Set, Group, Top, etc.

element-vs-set-confusion.description: Confusing elements of sets with sets as objects in the category Set
element-vs-set-confusion.recommendation: Understand the distinction between internal structure (elements) and categorical structure (objects and morphisms)
resources: Internal vs external perspective in categories

category-levels-confusion.description: Mixing up different levels of categorical abstraction (categories, functors, natural transformations)
category-levels-confusion.recommendation: Study the hierarchy: objects/morphisms → categories/functors → 2-categories/natural transformations

natural-vs-identity.description: Confusing natural transformations with identity functors or identity morphisms
natural-vs-identity.recommendation: Study specific examples of natural transformations and understand the naturality condition
resources: Classical natural transformations (determinant, double dual, etc.)

natural-vs-universal.description: Confusing natural transformations with universal properties or universal morphisms
natural-vs-universal.recommendation: Study both concepts separately and then understand their relationship through representable functors

naturality-condition.description: Missing the key requirement that natural transformations make certain diagrams commute
naturality-condition.recommendation: Practice drawing and verifying naturality squares for concrete examples
